Hi Derek, I had forgotten that they recorded that debate.  I enjoyed 
havin=
g the opportunity to ask my question to such illustrious 
scientists, but l=
ike you, I was kind of disappointed with their 
answers.  Like you said, th=
ey sort of answered accurately, but there 
was no real insight or thoughtfu=
lness in what they said.

It's interesting that you point out this exchange=
 because I think it 
highlights a weakness in how biologists have been deal=
ing with the 
question of complexity.  It's such a fundamental question yet=
 it 
hasn't really received the treatment it deserves, even from the 
field=
's luminaries.  I think part of the problem is that a genuine 
treatment re=
quires a kind of algorithmic and representational theory, 
which is perhaps=
 better attacked from a computational perspective, 
putting evolutionary co=
mputation researchers at an advantage because 
we think about search spaces=
, encodings, mappings, etc. routinely.  

Perhaps they were just being curt=
 or did not take the audience 
seriously enough to elaborate their thoughts=
.  Yet I find that 
explanation doubtful given that we were after all at a =
"debate" about 
evolution and complexity, which is precisely the substance =
of my 
question.  I also agree that Dawkins seemed closest to really 
think=
ing about it, so I'd guess Dawkins would be very interested in 
our area of=
 EC if only there was an opportunity to tell him about 
it.  But I don't th=
ink he has a great deal of experience with it 
beyond his old Blind Watchma=
ker demo.

On the bright side, the lack of clarity among the experts sugges=
ts a 
rare open opportunity to crack a major problem in biology and AI. 

k=
en

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Derek James" <djames@...> wrote:
>
> I ju=
st got around to viewing the video of the keynote discussion 
from
> GECCO =
2007, and it was nice to see that Ken had asked a question of
> the panel. =
Here's the link to the download:
> 
> http://www.cs.ucl.ac.uk/staff/p.bentl=
ey/evodebate.html
> 
> Ken asked: "How is it possible for 30,000 human gene=
s to encode the
> connectivity of a 100 trillion-connection brain? And how =
is it
> possible for evolution to search a space of such astronomical
> com=
plexity to discover such a structure?"
> 
> I was wondering what Ken though=
t of the answers to the question. I
> wasn't much impressed with them. Admi=
ttedly it's a difficult 
question,
> and the panel admitted that nobody rea=
lly knows. Jones seemed to say
> that there might be a lot more information=
 in DNA than we're giving 
it
> credit for, although he brought up Mandelbr=
ot sets as examples of
> complicated patterns that can arise from very simp=
le rules.
> 
> Wolpert didn't have much to say, though he seemed to say the=
 answer
> may lie in combinatorics. And Dawkins used the computer code 
ana=
logy,
> talking about the reuse of particular sections of code, which 
prob=
ably
> came closest to providing a decent answer, but none of them seemed
>=
 very satisfactory to me.
> 
> --Derek
>
